properties.name: 02/07/07 - City's terror scare
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlinePOLICE in Chester are stepping up patrols in the city to calm public fears after the weekend\'s terrorist attacks. Cheshire Constabulary is responding to terrorism incidents in London and Glasgow, by increasing high visibility patrols aimed at reassuring the public. Officers say although there is no specific intelligence singling out Chester as a target, the heightened fears of the public mean police are being extra vigilant with suspicious-looking vehicles and people. On Friday, Chester city centre was embroiled in the middle of a bomb scare. Cheshire police confirmed an area on Vicars Lane, near the Visitors Centre, was cordoned off at about 6.15pm, after a suitcase was found unattended at a bus stop. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2996815

properties.name: 02/07/07 - Cottage roof set on fire
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA THATCHED roof cottage was set on fire in the early hours of Saturday morning. Firefighters were called to the unoccupied property on Chester Road, Buckley at 2.25am. Two crews extinguished an area of the flaming roof, before the fire spread to the rest of the building. “The cause was deliberate ignition by persons unknown,” said a North Wales Fire and Rescue spokesman. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2996710

properties.name: 02/07/07 - TV celebrity helps open zoo’s new orangutan realm
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTELEVISION personality Nick Knowles visited Chester Zoo, to open a new sanctuary for critically endangered Sumatran and Bornean orangutans. The zoo\'s £3.5 million Realm of the Red Ape, Europe\'s largest orangutan enclosure, was officially open on Saturday. The opening marks the end of two years work developing the old enclosures into a state-of-the-art tropical home for the orangutans and a number of other Indonesian forest animals, including reptiles, birds, mammals. The enclosure also includes about 2,000 plants. Nick recently returned from a trip filming in Borneo, where he came face-to-face with orangutans to discover more about their plight in the wild. The film is for the BBC\'s Saving Planet Earth series, in which a number of different celebrities lend their support to threatened species. Nick said: "Having been to Borneo and seen the orangutans\' natural habitat and the rate at which it\'s disappearing, breeding programmes and the work being done at Chester Zoo become more important everyday." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2997359

properties.name: 03/07/07 - Armed police will patrol Wrexham
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineARMED police are to patrol Wrexham\'s key transport hubs in a bid to reassure the public over the terror threat facing Britain. In the wake of the failed car bomb attempts in London and the attack on Glasgow airport this weekend, police have moved quickly to monitor the situation in North Wales. The arrest yesterday of a man in Liverpool, as well as those of a man and a woman on the M6 in Cheshire, have heightened fears plotters could be operating in the region. Police will be at rail and bus stations, as well as pubs and other crowded areas. In a statement, the force said: "North Wales Police are taking prudent measures in light of the heightened security alert following the attacks in London and Glasgow. "In addition to the armed officers at the main port of Holyhead, highly visible armed officers will be on patrol at a number of train and bus stations, and also in other locations across the force area which may be vulnerable. "These include areas where large numbers of people may gather, as well as licensed premises. Checks along the main arterial routes within North Wales will also continue." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999100

properties.name: 03/07/07 - Chester's soldier killed in mortar blast
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA CHESTER man described as the "finest soldier of his generation" was killed in action in southern Afghanistan. Capt Sean Dolan, from 1st Battalion, The Worcestershire and Sherwood Foresters, died while on an operation with US and Afghan troops in Helmand province on Saturday. The 40-year-old, originally from the West Midlands but based in Chester, was observing Taliban fighters from a vantage point when he was killed by a mortar round. Tributes have been paid today to Capt Dolan, who was killed in the Sangin Valley area during an operation to maintain pressure on the Taliban. The Ministry of Defence described him as "undoubtedly regarded by all who had the honour of serving with him as the finest soldier of his generation". http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999708

properties.name: 03/07/07 - College fundraising a record-breaker
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineSTAFF and students at Deeside College are celebrating raising a record £32,138 for Marie Curie Cancer Care. After 18 months of fundraising, they formally presented the cheque at a celebration event at the college. The funds have been raised through a variety of events, including sponsored walks, the purchase of daffodils for lost loved ones, cake stalls, raffles, dragon boat racing and a casino night. One of the highlights of the year included catering lecturer Chris Griffiths\' 100-mile trek through Peru. Chris joined 32 others from across the UK to raise a combined total of more than £100,000 for Marie Curie. Chris alone raised £3,700. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999118

properties.name: 03/07/07 - Lottery winner revealed
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA LIVERPOOL fan from Wrexham has been celebrating on the terraces at his favourite football ground, Anfield, after \'kopping\' a £891,682 share of the Lotto jackpot. Marcus Lewis, 41, says the lottery win will definitely change his life. The railway engineer has supported Liverpool FC all his life and a season ticket for the \'Mighty Reds\' is now top of his \'premier league\' shopping list. Marcus, who is married to Amanda, 40, and has four children - David, 20, Jonathan ,17, Alice,15, and Lucy, 13 - only realised he had netted the jackpot after he took the ticket into a nearby shop to be checked. Marcus added: "This is something everyone dreams of. The machine told the shop assistant that it was a substantial amount of money. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2999866

properties.name: 03/07/07 - VIP opening as zoo leads way to save rare apes
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineEUROPE\'S largest orangutan enclosure has opened at Chester Zoo. TV presenter Nick Knowles was on hand to officially open the Realm of the Red Ape – a new £3.5m home for critically endangered Sumatran and Bornean orangutans. The official opening marks the end of two years\' work developing the old enclosures into a state-of-the-art tropical home for the orangutans and a number of other Indonesian forest animals, including reptiles, birds, and mammals. The enclosure includes some 2,000 plants. Nick said: "Having been to Borneo and seen the orangutan\'s natural habitat and the rate at which it\'s disappearing, breeding programmes and the work being done at Chester Zoo become more important every day." http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=2997540

properties.name: 04/07/07 - Lights, cameras, action as city named top location
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCHESTER has been named location of the month by a panel of top TV and film producers. The historic city has always been a firm favourite with tourists, but now it is starting to catch the attention of film and TV producers. Over the last 18 months Cheshire has seen a massive 49 per cent increase in the number of filming days taking place, and often its Chester which is top of their list of locations. Interest in the area has been so marked Chester has now been named July\'s Location of the Month by Northwest Vision + Media, which works on behalf of the TV, film, radio and digital content industries. One production that filmed in the city was BBC1\'s Lillies, which recorded at the City Baths. The Victorian pool provided the perfect backdrop to Lilies\' period story, set in the 1920s. More recently, a new advert for Crunchy Nut Cornflakes took to the banks of the River Dee, to film a boat race with a difference. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3002397

properties.name: 04/07/07 - Muggers strike as woman leaves hospital
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline A WOMAN who had just received hospital treatment was pushed on to her back before having her money stolen by two youths. The robbery happened in the grounds of the Countess of Chester hospital at about 2.50pm on Saturday. The 30-year-old woman was walking towards a newsagent on Liverpool Road when she was approached from behind by two youths wearing blue hoodies. She had just taken some money from her pocket and the youths tried to snatch the money from her grip. As she resisted, the youths pushed her on to her back before snatching her money and running away towards the city. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3002268

properties.name: 04/07/07 - PICTURE AND VIDEO SPECIAL - Castle Cement tower blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA selection of images sent in by readers during the dramatic fire at the Padeswood plant. Thanks to all our readers who sent in their images, videos and comments to digitalnews@nwn.co.uk To see the pictures and videos click the following link: http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3002198

properties.name: 04/07/07 - Robber demanded cash after breaking into victims home
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WOMAN was threatened by a knife-wielding intruder in her bedroom. The 44-year-old was in bed at her home on Karen Way, Great Sutton, Ellesmere Port, at about 11pm on on Sunday, when a teenage boy entered the premises. He went upstairs, threatened her with a long-bladed kitchen knife, and demanded money. Anna Galloway, of Cheshire Constabulary, said: "He then searched the premises before stealing a quantity of cash and property. He left through the front door." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3003890

properties.name: 04/07/07 - £100,000 revamp for library
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA VILLAGE library is to undergo a facelift after nearly £100,000 in grant funding was secured. Rhos Library has been picked out from a number of projects nationwide to benefit from cash from the Welsh Assembly. The money will be spent to improve the building\'s facilities, in particular for community groups, schools and young adults and disabled people. Clwyd South AM, Karen Sinclair welcomed the news, which she said would mean a "significant" makeover for the library. She said: "Libraries are vital for members of our community who can\'t access the very latest up-to-date technology in their own homes." Ms Sinclair added that children, parents with young families and pensioners would all benefit from the new facilities on offer thanks to the investment. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3000668

properties.name: 05/05/07 - Councillors back £500,000 plans to strengthen bridge
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA ROAD bridge is to be strengthened at a cost of £500,000. Councillors have given their backing to work to strengthen Pont Felin Puleston, which carries the A5152 Wrexham to Rhostyllen road over the River Clywedog. They also agreed to authorise compulsory purchase powers to acquire land required to carry out the scheme. A report to Wrexham Council\'s executive board said the work was long overdue, and added: "Negotiations with owners of land required for the scheme commenced in September 1996 but the scheme fell through owing to lack of funding. Recent attempts to resurrect the scheme have been halted because some of the land required is owned by the National Trust and cannot be sold to the council unless the council uses its statutory powers to acquire it." Councillors were told that if no objections to the compulsory purchase order were lodged the work could start next summer. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3003855

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Airman making miracle recovery after 12 month coma
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA WREXHAM airman who survived a mystery roadside incident, which left him in a coma for months, is battling back Greg Vickers was left fighting for his life in Borras Park, in September, 2005. He suffered serious head injuries and spent several months in a coma. A partial recovery meant he was able to return home in December, and the rate of his progress since then has been a revelation. And now keen sportsman Greg is even back at the crease, playing cricket under the supervision of coach Paul Cartwright. Paul said: "In the six weeks I have been working with Greg, I have seen a big difference. He is coming on all the time and it is amazing to see. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3006712

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Boy racers driving flat dwellers to distraction
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA GROUP of angry residents whose lives are blighted by boy racers on the streets of Chester have started a petition in the hope of blitzing the problem. People living in the Newtown flats in Chester, who are tired of being kept awake by the antics of the boy racers, are hoping the petition will raise awareness of the situation to the police. Tony McCabe, of St Anne\'s flats, told the Leader that cars have been gathering in the Gorse Stacks car park late at night and then racing around the roads, leaving residents suffering sleepless nights. He said: "These boy racers are using Chester as if it was a Monaco Grand Prix. From about 10pm onwards they park in the car park before the gates are locked and then they do full circuits of the dual carriageway." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3004540

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Carer Bill prepares for life without his 'marvellous girl'
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA DOTING husband who wrote an inspiring booklet about caring for his wife through her Alzheimer\'s illness is facing life without her. Since 2004, Bill Tuer has raised more than £4,000 for the Flintshire branch of the Alzheimer\'s Society by selling his booklet Caring for Marjorie. After suffering with dementia for more than 15 years, Marjorie died a fortnight ago aged 90. Bill, 86, who lives in Eryrys, Mold, first met Marjorie when he was 14-years-old and the son of the head gamekeeper on the Reynold\'s family Iscoyd Park estate, near Whitchurch. At the time, Marjorie was 17 and was the lady of the house\'s personal maid. After Bill became Marjorie\'s full-time carer a support carer suggested he write some of his memories down as a therapeutic way of keeping his mind off things and soon he had written his memoirs A Prince Among Poachers. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3006633

properties.name: 05/07/07 - City set for 'war of the buses'
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA "WAR on the buses" is set to break out across Chester following the historic sale of Chester City Transport. On Monday evening, Chester City Council completed the sale of its bus stock to First Group, Britain\'s largest bus operator. It was heralded as the deal that would secure the future of bus services in the city, but has now been overshadowed by rival company Arriva\'s plans to launch an extra 18 bus services an hour from the city centre bus exchange, which is already operating above capacity. Arriva\'s proposals to introduce an additional 12 services an hour to Blacon and a further six an hour to Saughall follow a high-profile court battle, which was initiated by the city council\'s former cabinet. http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3008569

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Doctor's plea: 'Dont't let bombers tarnish our image'
properties.description: Posted by Leaderonline THE head of a top doctors\' group has moved to reassure the public after eight doctors or people linked to the NHS were arrested over the London and Glasgow car bombs. Dr Jay Nankani, of the Hillcrest Surgery, Holt Road, Wrexham, is chairman of the GP forum of the British International Doctors Association. He said people should not allow the arrests to tarnish the image of his profession. "I, and the group, would like to condemn any form of terrorism, and the activities of those involved in London and Glasgow," he said. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3004711

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Environment Agency to investigate Castle blaze
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineCASTLE Cement has moved to reassure residents it\'s business as usual at the Padeswood plant following a blaze that took 14 hours to bring under control. Firefighters were called to the plant at 12.14pm on Tuesday to deal with a fire on a conveyer belt. Initially, two crews from Deeside, a crew from Buckley, a crew from Wrexham, the aerial ladder platform, environmental protection unit and incident command unit from Wrexham were at the scene. Just after 3.30pm exhausted firefighters called for relief and crews from Flint, Johnstown, Ruthin and St Asaph and the incident command unit from Colwyn Bay were drafted in. The aerial ladder platform from Wrexham returned to the scene at 7.09pm and at 7.37pm and 8.23pm crews from Wrexham and Deeside replaced those from Flint, Johnstown, Ruthin and St Asaph. The last crew left the scene at 2:20am yesterday and North Wales Fire and Rescue Service are investigating the cause of the fire. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3006583

properties.name: 05/07/07 - Work starts on Eisteddfod tent with 30 days to go
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineTHE countdown has finally begun to one of the biggest events in Flintshire\'s history with just 30 days left until the National Eisteddfod begins. Construction of the National Eisteddfod\'s main pavilion on the Pentrehobyn Estate commenced yesterday, with electric winches hauling giant metal support legs into place. Chief executive of the National Eisteddfod, Elfed Roberts, was in Mold yesterday to witness the giant pavilion being erected and said it was \'quite an exciting sight to see\'. http://www.eveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3007378

properties.name: 06/07/07 - War of words over claims city walls are a danger to public
properties.description: Posted by LeaderonlineA furious war of words has broken out over the state of Chester\'s historic walls, amid claims they are unsafe to the public. Liberal Democrat councillor Jean Evans claims a report from Chester City Council\'s design and conservation manager Howard Dickenson refutes claims made by local Conservatives before the election that the walls were a threat to public safety. Cllr Evans said the Conservatives had claimed there was something wrong with the walls and that the last administration was pretending there wasn\'t. She said: "We realised there was something wrong which needed to be fixed and started working for that to be done. "The Conservatives are claiming there is a threat to public safety, and the walls could become unsafe, but the city does not have control where they are moving – where they are adjoined to the Grosvenor Hotel car park – as it lies on someone else\'s land and they are reluctant to have work done." http://www.chestereveningleader.co.uk/news?articleid=3008273
